You are here:

SALESFORCE HELP
DOCS
VISUALFORCE B2B COMMERCE
Control Traffic from Search Engines with robots.txt

To help manage search engine bot activity on your storefront pages, a robots.txt file links to your sitemap index and specifies URLs to block from being crawled. B2B Commerce for Visualforce provides a default robots.txt file that you can assign to your Experience Cloud site. You can also create a custom robots.txt file, depending on your storefront setup and the pages you want to block from being crawled.

REQUIRED EDITIONS AND USER PERMISSIONS

Salesforce Compatibility

Salesforce Classic (not available in all orgs) and Lightning Experience for Enterprise, Performance, Unlimited, and Developer editions.




B2B Commerce Compatibility

B2B Commerce for Visualforce Winter ’21 (version 4.13)
B2B Commerce for Visualforce Spring ’20 (version 4.12)
B2B Commerce for Visualforce Summer ’19 (version 4.11)
B2B Commerce for Visualforce Spring ’19 (version 4.10)
B2B Commerce for Visualforce Summer ’18 (version 4.9)


USER PERMISSIONS NEEDED
To create, customize, or publish an Experience Cloud site:	

Create and Set Up Experiences

AND

View Setup and Configuration

NOTE Even if you block some URLs from being crawled, search engine bots can still learn about blocked pages by crawling other pages that link to them. For more information, check out Google documentation on robots.txt.

Here’s an example of the default robots.txtfile.

<apex:page contentType="text/plain" showHeader="false">
User-agent: *
Disallow: /ccrz__MyAccount?
Disallow: /ccrz__Cart?
Disallow: /ccrz__CCForgotPassword?
Disallow: /ccrz__CCSiteRegister?
Sitemap: domain/apex/ccrz__CCSiteIndex
</apex:page>

Use the default robots.txt when:

Your storefront is at the root of your domain. For example, storefront users visit MyDomainName.my.site.com instead of MyDomainName.my.site.com/MyStore.
You want robots.txt to link to your sitemap index so that search engine bots can find your category sitemaps quickly.
You want to block the My Account page, Shopping Cart page, Forgot Password page, and Site Register page from being crawled. These pages typically contain dynamic, session-specific content that you don’t want search engines to index.

Create a custom robots.txt when:

Your storefront isn’t at the root of your domain. Storefront users visit MyDomainName.my.site.com/MyStore.
You want to override the behavior of the default robots.txt, such as to block all crawling of your storefront or to reference a custom sitemap index.
You want to reference sitemap indexes for multiple storefronts from a single robots.txt.
Depending on whether you’re enabling the default robots.txt or creating a custom robots.txt, set up the appropriate resources.
To use the default robots.txt, first configure your storefront to be at the root of your domain.
To use a custom robots.txt, create a Visualforce page with your custom robots.txt details.
From Setup, enter Sites in the Quick Find box, and then select All Sites under Digital Experiences.
Click Workspaces next to your site, and then click the Administration workspace tile.
From the Administration menu, select Pages, and then click Go to Force.com.
In the site details, click Edit.
For Site Robots.txt Page, enter the name of the file you want to use and click Save.
To use the default robots.txt, enter cc_Robots.txt.
To use a custom robots.txt, enter the name of the Visualforce page you created.
NOTE To ensure that your sitemap URLs are complete, verify that you’ve specified a Site Secure Domain for your storefront in CC Admin | Storefront Name | General.
TIP Are you using B2B Commerce for Visualforce Winter ’21 (version 4.13) or later with an Experience Builder page as your storefront's Home page? To include the Experience Builder page sitemap in your custom robots.txt file, first manually generate a sitemap from Experience Builder. Then, set the Lightning Community Sitemap configuration in the User Interface module to TRUE. For more information, see Specify the Destination for Links to Your Storefront's Home Page.

title: Managing Search Engine Traffic with robots.txt
